Article.Abstract: We have previously demonstrated that the Mycobacterium leprae 18-kD heat shock protein (HSP18) is represented among the antigenic targets of human T cell responses induced by M. leprae immunization and that the peptide 38-50 serves as an immunodominant epitope recognized by CD4+ T cell clones. By using peripheral blood mononuclear cells and T cell lines from the same donor group, we have in this study shown that the M. leprae HSP18 and peptide 38-50 were recognized by memory T cells 8 years after immunization with M. leprae. The finding that M. bovis BCG-induced T cell lines responded to M. leprae HSP18, but not to the peptide 38-50, suggested the existence of additional T cell epitopes of a cross-reactive nature. Consistent with this, testing of the T cell lines for proliferative responses to the complete HSP18 molecule, truncated HSP18 (amino acid (aa) residues 38-148) and overlapping synthetic peptides, made it possible to identify two cross-reactive epitope regions defined by aa residues 1-38 and 41-55. While peptide 38-50-reactive T cell clones showed limited cross-reactivity by responding to M. leprae, M. avium and M. scrofulaceum, the T cell lines specific to the epitopes 1-38 and 41-55 were broadly cross-reactive, as demonstrated by their response to M. leprae, M. tuberculosis complex, M. avium and other mycobacteria. MHC restriction analysis of the HSP18-responding T cell lines showed that the epitopes 1-38 and 38-50 were presented by one of the two HLA-DR molecules expressed from self HLA-DRB1 genes, whereas the epitope 41-55 was recognized in the presence of autologous as well as HLA-DR and HLA-DQ mismatched allogeneic antigen-presenting cells. The results obtained in this study made it possible to identify cross-reactive T cell epitopes of the M. leprae HSP18, and provide an explanation for T cell recognition of this antigen in individuals infected with species of the M. tuberculosis complex or environmental mycobacteria.
Article.ArticleTitle: Cross-reactive epitopes and HLA-restriction elements in human T cell recognition of the Mycobacterium leprae 18-kD heat shock protein.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were derived from PBMCs collected from HLA-typed healthy subjects immunized with M. bovis BCG in childhood and M. leprae in adulthood. T cell lines were generated by long term incubation with M. leprae.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific T cell lines proliferated in response to related organism M. scrofulaceum.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were derived from PBMCs collected from HLA-typed healthy subjects immunized with M. bovis BCG in childhood and M. leprae in adulthood. T cell lines were generated by long term incubation with M. leprae.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific T cell lines proliferated in response to the whole HSP18 protein.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific T cell lines proliferated in response to M. leprae.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: T cell lines were derived from PBMCs collected from HLA-typed healthy subjects immunized with M. bovis BCG in childhood and M. leprae in adulthood. T cell lines were generated by long term incubation with M. leprae.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific T cell lines derived from the PBMCs of M. leprae-immunized individuals proliferated in response to related organism M. bovis BCG.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were collected from five HLA-typed healthy subjects immunized with M. bovis BCG in childhood and M. leprae in adulthood. M. leprae- and M. bovis BCG-specific T cell lines were also generated.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMCs from M. leprae-immunized individuals proliferated in response to the epitope. In a separate assay, M. leprae-induced T cell lines from these same individuals were also shown to proliferate in 3 out of 5 of those tested. No proliferation was observed in BCG-induced T cell lines. The 3 positive responders were HLA-DR4 positive, whereas the non-responders were DR4 negative.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T cell lines derived from the PBMCs of M. leprae-immunized individuals proliferated in response to the epitope. This epitope was recognized by autologous, as well as HLA-DR and HLA-DQ mismatched allogeneic APCs.
